desc_content.paragraph: The BMesh data structure
Calculate triangle tessellation from quads/ngons.
Calculate mesh volume based on face normals.

field_body.paragraph: signed (bool) – when signed is true, negative values may be returned.

desc_content.paragraph: Clear all mesh data.
Explicitly free the BMesh data from memory, causing exceptions on further access.

note.paragraph: The BMesh is freed automatically, typically when the script finishes executing. However in some cases its hard to predict when this will be and its useful to explicitly free the data.

desc_content.paragraph: Initialize this bmesh from existing mesh datablock.

list_item.paragraph: mesh (Mesh) – The mesh data to load.
use_shape_key (boolean) – Use the locations from a shape key.
shape_key_index (int) – The shape key index to use.

note.paragraph: Multiple calls can be used to join multiple meshes.
Custom-data layers are only copied from mesh on initialization. Further calls will copy custom-data to matching layers, layers missing on the target mesh wont be added.

desc_content.paragraph: Initialize this bmesh from existing object datablock (currently only meshes are supported).

list_item.paragraph: object (Object) – The object data to load.
deform (boolean) – Apply deformation modifiers.
render (boolean) – Use render settings.
cage (boolean) – Get the mesh as a deformed cage.
face_normals (boolean) – Calculate face normals.

desc_content.paragraph: Update mesh normals.
Flush selection, independent of the current selection mode.

field_body.paragraph: select (boolean) – flush selection or de-selected elements.

desc_content.paragraph: flush selection based on the current mode current BMesh.select_mode.
Writes this BMesh data into an existing Mesh datablock.

field_body.paragraph: mesh (Mesh) – The mesh data to write into.

desc_content.paragraph: Transform the mesh (optionally filtering flagged data only).

list_item.paragraph: matrix (4x4 mathutils.Matrix) – transform matrix.
filter (set) – set of values in (‘SELECT’, ‘HIDE’, ‘SEAM’, ‘SMOOTH’, ‘TAG’).

desc_content.paragraph: This meshes edge sequence (read-only).
This meshes face sequence (read-only).
True when this element is valid (hasn’t been removed).
True when this mesh is owned by blender (typically the editmode BMesh).
This meshes loops (read-only).

note.paragraph: Loops must be accessed via faces, this is only exposed for layer access.

desc_content.paragraph: Sequence of selected items (the last is displayed as active).
The selection mode, values can be {‘VERT’, ‘EDGE’, ‘FACE’}, can’t be assigned an empty set.
This meshes vert sequence (read-only).
The BMesh vertex type
Return the angle between this vert’s two connected edges.

field_body.paragraph: fallback (any) – return this when the vert doesn’t have 2 edges (instead of raising a ValueError).

desc_content.paragraph: Return a multiplier calculated based on the sharpness of the vertex. Where a flat surface gives 1.0, and higher values sharper edges. This is used to maintain shell thickness when offsetting verts along their normals.
Copy values from another element of matching type.
Interpolate the customdata from a face onto this loop (the loops vert should overlap the face).

field_body.paragraph: face (BMFace) – The face to interpolate data from.

desc_content.paragraph: Interpolate the customdata from a vert between 2 other verts.

field_body.paragraph: vert_pair (BMVert) – The vert to interpolate data from.

desc_content.paragraph: Set the hide state. This is different from the hide attribute because it updates the selection and hide state of associated geometry.
Update vertex normal.
Set the selection. This is different from the select attribute because it updates the selection state of associated geometry.

note.paragraph: Currently this only flushes down, so selecting a face will select all its vertices but de-selecting a vertex won’t de-select all the faces that use it, before finishing with a mesh typically flushing is still needed.

desc_content.paragraph: The coordinates for this vertex as a 3D, wrapped vector.
Hidden state of this element.
Index of this element.

note.paragraph: This value is not necessarily valid, while editing the mesh it can become dirty.
It’s also possible to assign any number to this attribute for a scripts internal logic.
To ensure the value is up to date - see BMElemSeq.index_update.

desc_content.paragraph: True when this vertex is connected to boundary edges (read-only).
True when this vertex is manifold (read-only).
True when this element is valid (hasn’t been removed).
True when this vertex is not connected to any faces (read-only).
Edges connected to this vertex (read-only).
Faces connected to this vertex (read-only).
Loops that use this vertex (read-only).
The normal for this vertex as a 3D, wrapped vector.
Selected state of this element.
Generic attribute scripts can use for own logic
The BMesh edge connecting 2 verts

field_body.paragraph: fallback (any) – return this when the edge doesn’t have 2 faces (instead of raising a ValueError).
The angle between 2 connected faces in radians.
fallback (any) – return this when the edge doesn’t have 2 faces (instead of raising a ValueError).
The angle between 2 connected faces in radians (negative for concave join).

desc_content.paragraph: Return the tangent at this edge relative to a face (pointing inward into the face). This uses the face normal for calculation.

field_body.paragraph: loop (BMLoop) – The loop used for tangent calculation.

desc_content.paragraph: Copy values from another element of matching type.
Set the hide state. This is different from the hide attribute because it updates the selection and hide state of associated geometry.
Update edges vertex normals.
Return the other vertex on this edge or None if the vertex is not used by this edge.

field_body.paragraph: vert (BMVert) – a vert in this edge.

desc_content.paragraph: Set the selection. This is different from the select attribute because it updates the selection state of associated geometry.

note.paragraph: Currently this only flushes down, so selecting a face will select all its vertices but de-selecting a vertex won’t de-select all the faces that use it, before finishing with a mesh typically flushing is still needed.

desc_content.paragraph: Hidden state of this element.
Index of this element.

note.paragraph: This value is not necessarily valid, while editing the mesh it can become dirty.
It’s also possible to assign any number to this attribute for a scripts internal logic.
To ensure the value is up to date - see BMElemSeq.index_update.

desc_content.paragraph: True when this edge is at the boundary of a face (read-only).
True when this edge is manifold, between two faces with the same winding (read-only).
True when this edge joins two convex faces, depends on a valid face normal (read-only).
True when this edge is manifold (read-only).
True when this element is valid (hasn’t been removed).
True when this edge is not connected to any faces (read-only).
Faces connected to this edge, (read-only).
Loops connected to this edge, (read-only).
Seam for UV unwrapping.
Selected state of this element.
Smooth state of this element.
Generic attribute scripts can use for own logic
Verts this edge uses (always 2), (read-only).
The BMesh face with 3 or more sides
Return the area of the face.

field_body.paragraph: Return the area of the face.

desc_content.paragraph: Return bounds center of the face.
Return median center of the face.
Return median center of the face weighted by edge lengths.
Return the perimeter of the face.

field_body.paragraph: Return the perimeter of the face.

desc_content.paragraph: Return face tangent based on longest edge.
Return face tangent based on the edge farthest from any vertex.
Return face tangent based on the two longest disconnected edges.

list_item.paragraph: Tris: Use the edge pair with the most similar lengths.
Quads: Use the longest edge pair.
NGons: Use the two longest disconnected edges.

desc_content.paragraph: Return face tangent based on the two most distent vertices.
Make a copy of this face.

list_item.paragraph: verts (boolean) – When set, the faces verts will be duplicated too.
edges (boolean) – When set, the faces edges will be duplicated too.

desc_content.paragraph: Copy values from another element of matching type.
Interpolate the customdata from another face onto this one (faces should overlap).

list_item.paragraph: face (BMFace) – The face to interpolate data from.
vert (boolean) – When True, also copy vertex data.

desc_content.paragraph: Set the hide state. This is different from the hide attribute because it updates the selection and hide state of associated geometry.
Reverses winding of a face, which flips its normal.
Update face’s normal.
Set the selection. This is different from the select attribute because it updates the selection state of associated geometry.

note.paragraph: Currently this only flushes down, so selecting a face will select all its vertices but de-selecting a vertex won’t de-select all the faces that use it, before finishing with a mesh typically flushing is still needed.

desc_content.paragraph: Edges of this face, (read-only).
Hidden state of this element.
Index of this element.

note.paragraph: This value is not necessarily valid, while editing the mesh it can become dirty.
It’s also possible to assign any number to this attribute for a scripts internal logic.
To ensure the value is up to date - see BMElemSeq.index_update.

desc_content.paragraph: True when this element is valid (hasn’t been removed).
Loops of this face, (read-only).
The face’s material index.
The normal for this face as a 3D, wrapped vector.
Selected state of this element.
Smooth state of this element.
Generic attribute scripts can use for own logic
Verts of this face, (read-only).
This is normally accessed from BMFace.loops where each face loop represents a corner of the face.
Return the angle at this loops corner of the face. This is calculated so sharper corners give lower angles.
Return normal at this loops corner of the face. Falls back to the face normal for straight lines.
Return the tangent at this loops corner of the face (pointing inward into the face). Falls back to the face normal for straight lines.
Copy values from another element of matching type.
Interpolate the customdata from a face onto this loop (the loops vert should overlap the face).

list_item.paragraph: face (BMFace) – The face to interpolate data from.
vert (boolean) – When enabled, interpolate the loops vertex data (optional).
multires (boolean) – When enabled, interpolate the loops multires data (optional).

desc_content.paragraph: The loop’s edge (between this loop and the next), (read-only).
The face this loop makes (read-only).
Index of this element.

note.paragraph: This value is not necessarily valid, while editing the mesh it can become dirty.
It’s also possible to assign any number to this attribute for a scripts internal logic.
To ensure the value is up to date - see BMElemSeq.index_update.

desc_content.paragraph: True when this loop is at the convex corner of a face, depends on a valid face normal (read-only).
True when this element is valid (hasn’t been removed).
The next face corner (read-only).
The previous face corner (read-only).
The next loop around the edge (read-only).
The previous loop around the edge (read-only).
Loops connected to this loop, (read-only).
Generic attribute scripts can use for own logic
The loop’s vertex (read-only).
General sequence type used for accessing any sequence of BMVert, BMEdge, BMFace, BMLoop.
When accessed via BMesh.verts, BMesh.edges, BMesh.faces there are also functions to create/remomove items.
Initialize the index values of this sequence.
This is the equivalent of looping over all elements and assigning the index values.
desc_content.literal_block: for index, ele in enumerate(sequence): ele.index = index

note.paragraph: Running this on sequences besides BMesh.verts, BMesh.edges, BMesh.faces works but won’t result in each element having a valid index, insted its order in the sequence will be set.

desc_content.paragraph: Ensure internal data needed for int subscription is initialized with verts/edges/faces, eg bm.verts[index].
This needs to be called again after adding/removing data in this sequence.
Initialize the index values of this sequence.
This is the equivalent of looping over all elements and assigning the index values.
desc_content.literal_block: for index, ele in enumerate(sequence): ele.index = index

note.paragraph: Running this on sequences besides BMesh.verts, BMesh.edges, BMesh.faces works but won’t result in each element having a valid index, insted its order in the sequence will be set.

desc_content.paragraph: Create a new vertex.

list_item.paragraph: co (float triplet) – The initial location of the vertex (optional argument).
example (BMVert) – Existing vert to initialize settings.

desc_content.paragraph: Remove a vert.
Sort the elements of this sequence, using an optional custom sort key. Indices of elements are not changed, BMElemeSeq.index_update() can be used for that.

list_item.paragraph: key – The key that sets the ordering of the elements.
reverse – Reverse the order of the elements

note.paragraph: When the ‘key’ argument is not provided, the elements are reordered following their current index value. In particular this can be used by setting indices manually before calling this method.

warning.paragraph: Existing references to the N’th element, will continue to point the data at that index.

desc_content.paragraph: custom-data layers (read-only).
Ensure internal data needed for int subscription is initialized with verts/edges/faces, eg bm.verts[index].
This needs to be called again after adding/removing data in this sequence.
Return an edge which uses the verts passed.

list_item.paragraph: verts (BMVert) – Sequence of verts.
fallback – Return this value if nothing is found.

desc_content.paragraph: Initialize the index values of this sequence.
This is the equivalent of looping over all elements and assigning the index values.
desc_content.literal_block: for index, ele in enumerate(sequence): ele.index = index

note.paragraph: Running this on sequences besides BMesh.verts, BMesh.edges, BMesh.faces works but won’t result in each element having a valid index, insted its order in the sequence will be set.

desc_content.paragraph: Create a new edge from a given pair of verts.

list_item.paragraph: verts (pair of BMVert) – Vertex pair.
example (BMEdge) – Existing edge to initialize settings (optional argument).

desc_content.paragraph: Remove an edge.
Sort the elements of this sequence, using an optional custom sort key. Indices of elements are not changed, BMElemeSeq.index_update() can be used for that.

list_item.paragraph: key – The key that sets the ordering of the elements.
reverse – Reverse the order of the elements

note.paragraph: When the ‘key’ argument is not provided, the elements are reordered following their current index value. In particular this can be used by setting indices manually before calling this method.

warning.paragraph: Existing references to the N’th element, will continue to point the data at that index.

desc_content.paragraph: custom-data layers (read-only).
Ensure internal data needed for int subscription is initialized with verts/edges/faces, eg bm.verts[index].
This needs to be called again after adding/removing data in this sequence.
Return a face which uses the verts passed.

list_item.paragraph: verts (BMVert) – Sequence of verts.
fallback – Return this value if nothing is found.

desc_content.paragraph: Initialize the index values of this sequence.
This is the equivalent of looping over all elements and assigning the index values.
desc_content.literal_block: for index, ele in enumerate(sequence): ele.index = index

note.paragraph: Running this on sequences besides BMesh.verts, BMesh.edges, BMesh.faces works but won’t result in each element having a valid index, insted its order in the sequence will be set.

desc_content.paragraph: Create a new face from a given set of verts.

list_item.paragraph: verts (BMVert) – Sequence of 3 or more verts.
example (BMFace) – Existing face to initialize settings (optional argument).

desc_content.paragraph: Remove a face.
Sort the elements of this sequence, using an optional custom sort key. Indices of elements are not changed, BMElemeSeq.index_update() can be used for that.

list_item.paragraph: key – The key that sets the ordering of the elements.
reverse – Reverse the order of the elements

note.paragraph: When the ‘key’ argument is not provided, the elements are reordered following their current index value. In particular this can be used by setting indices manually before calling this method.

warning.paragraph: Existing references to the N’th element, will continue to point the data at that index.

desc_content.paragraph: active face.
custom-data layers (read-only).
custom-data layers (read-only).
Internal BMesh type for looping over verts/faces/edges, used for iterating over BMElemSeq types.
Add an element to the selection history (no action taken if its already added).
Empties the selection history.
Discard an element from the selection history.
Like remove but doesn’t raise an error when the elements not in the selection list.
Remove an element from the selection history.
Ensures all elements in the selection history are selected.
The last selected element or None (read-only).
Exposes custom-data layer attributes.
Bevel weight float in [0 - 1].
Vertex deform weight BMDeformVert (TODO).

Accessor for BMLoopUV UV (as a 2D Vector).
type: BMLayerCollection
Gives access to a collection of custom-data layers of the same type and behaves like python dictionaries, except for the ability to do list like index access.
Returns the value of the layer matching the key or default when not found (matches pythons dictionary function of the same name).

list_item.paragraph: key (string) – The key associated with the layer.
default (Undefined) – Optional argument for the value to return if key is not found.

desc_content.paragraph: Return the identifiers of collection members (matching pythons dict.items() functionality).

field_body.paragraph: (key, value) pairs for each member of this collection.

desc_content.paragraph: Return the identifiers of collection members (matching pythons dict.keys() functionality).

field_body.paragraph: the identifiers for each member of this collection.

desc_content.paragraph: Create a new layer

field_body.paragraph: name (string) – Optional name argument (will be made unique).

desc_content.paragraph: Remove a layer
Return the values of collection (matching pythons dict.values() functionality).
Create a new layer or return an existing active layer
The active layer of this type (read-only).
True if there can exists only one layer of this type (read-only).
Exposes a single custom data layer, their main purpose is for use as item accessors to custom-data when used with vert/edge/face/loop data.
Return a copy of the layer

list_item.paragraph: other – Another layer to copy from.
other – BMLayerItem

desc_content.paragraph: The layers unique name (read-only).
UV pin state.
UV select state.
UV edge select state.
Loops UV (as a 2D Vector).
Clears all weights.
Returns the deform weight matching the key or default when not found (matches pythons dictionary function of the same name).

list_item.paragraph: key (int) – The key associated with deform weight.
default (Undefined) – Optional argument for the value to return if key is not found.

desc_content.paragraph: Return (group, weight) pairs for this vertex (matching pythons dict.items() functionality).

field_body.paragraph: (key, value) pairs for each deform weight of this vertex.

desc_content.paragraph: Return the group indices used by this vertex (matching pythons dict.keys() functionality).

field_body.paragraph: the deform group this vertex uses

desc_content.paragraph: Return the weights of the deform vertex (matching pythons dict.values() functionality).

field_body.paragraph: The weights that influence this vertex
